record.description: [Photographic copy of a drawing.] Mr. Emery B. Jackson created a twelve-foot long Midway perspective [drawing] of the proposed [University of Chicago] library for Shepley, Rutan and Coolidge. Sent to England for rendering, the work (circa 1915) sustained water damage and was destroyed by fire in 1930. The extant photographic print was made from a glass plate negative.
record.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center
record.noteGeneral: From two notes included with the photo and dating from August 2, 1945 and July 1946: The perspective laid out by Mr. Emery B. Jackson, in the office of Shipley, Rutan and Coolidge was about 12 feet long and was executed about 1910. It was then sent to England for rendering. In 1930, the original image drawing was damaged by fire and water while in the care of Charles Hodgdon and Sons, Architects. This firm kept it in the third floor of an uncompleted building. This is a copy of a 1915 print made from a damaged lantern slide.
